thread.title: Brutal reality justifying Muscat snubbing star
thread.title_full: Brutal reality justifying Muscat snubbing star

title: Brutal reality justifying Muscat snubbing star
text:
Kozzy: He won't play again 1:34 Mark Rudan says Fahid Ben Khalfallah’s form created a tough call for Kevin Muscat to balance  25am @annaharrington Source: FOX SPORTS THE sight of Melbourne Victory winger Fahid Ben Khalfallah cutting a forlorn figure in the stands on Saturday night sent a buzz of confusion through A-League fans. 
When Robbie Slater said he believed the fan favourite was being deliberately left out for contractual reasons, that confusion quickly turned to indignation. 
After all, Ben Khalfallah has been a fine servant for Melbourne Victory — while his recent run of good form had contributed to his club’s own purple patch. 
It seemed excruciatingly unfair that the winger could reportedly be on the outer to avoid triggering a games clause in his contract that would give him another year at the A-League powerhouse. 
But former Sydney FC captain Mark Rudan told foxsports.com.au Khalfallah’s inconsistent form at the club may have made Victory’s need to make a call on his future — especially given the winger is currently a well-paid player who takes up a visa spot — more pressing, even though it could impact this season. 
He wants to play, is fit to play and fans enjoy watching him. But Victory clearly are reluctant to lock themselves in to keeping him next season. 
Every game of every round LIVE & ad-break free during play on FOX SPORTS. Get your free 2-week FOXTEL PLAY trial and start watching in minutes. SIGN UP NOW > 
“Now when it comes to Ben Khalfallah and his form this year, well I believe his form’s been up and down,” Rudan said. 
“He didn’t start the season all that well, so his form has fluctuated, and then he had a good run of games and now he finds himself in this position. 
“So you can understand from Kevin (Muscat) if it’s purely based on form, well he has had an up and down season. That’s my belief. 
“But you still feel for Ben Khalfallah when you see him up in the stands — suited up and watching the game from the stands — it’s a pretty tough one for him to take as well. 
“So there’s obviously two sides to the story here but it’s not the first time it’s happened and it’s not the last time.” 
THE PATCHY FORM THAT COULD HAVE JUSTIFIED FBK SNUB 
To say Ben Khalfallah’s form has fluctuated would be accurate — in terms of both this year and his Victory career overall. 
The winger burst onto the scene in 2014 and played a crucial role in Victory securing the Premiership/Championship double in the 2014/15 season. 
After reportedly being in heavy demand in the A-League — with Perth Glory reportedly particularly keen to secure his services — Ben Khalfallah signed a new two-year deal with Victory in April 2015. Ben Khalfallah and Muscat celebrate the 2014/15 A-League Grand Final. Source: Getty Images 
This year, his form suffered severely, with Ben Khalfallah well down on his best. 
Off the back of a horrendous performance as an attacking midfielder in the Victory’s Melbourne Derby drubbing, the Tunisian looked almost set to simply see out his contract at the club, with Mitch Austin preferred ahead of him on the wing. 
But then came a masterful performance against Western Sydney, where Ben Khalfallah’s brilliance was on full show as he orchestrated a 3-0 home win. 
Since then, the winger has started all but one game, with the most recent Melbourne Derby on February 4 his latest appearance. 
Now, it appears it could be difficult to see the fan favourite front up in Victory colours again. 
A DIFFICULT SITUATION TO HANDLE 
Rudan said the situation was especially difficult for Victory manager Kevin Muscat. 
“It’s definitely not an easy one from Kevin Muscat’s point of view,” Rudan said. 
“He’s clearly trying to do what’s best for his football club and that’s the job of a coach. 
“Now, unfortunately for a coach, you have to deal with 20-odd players in your squad and everybody is in a different situation. 
“It just so happens that Ben Khalfallah incident has come up and it’s a situation that it’s really hard to find any medium ground because someone’s going to be disappointed along the way. 
“So I feel for Ben Khalfallah if what has been discussed is true — if he’s being left out of the squad because it may trigger another year in his contract if he plays another game. I do feel for him. 
“But like I said, it’s not an easy one for Kevin Muscat, it really isn’t — or for any coach for that matter.” Besart Belisha, Fahid Ben Khalfallah and Marco Rojas celebrate a goal. Source: News Corp Australia 
Rudan said he didn’t believe the club’s situation would affect the club’s mindset heading into finals. 
“Some players who are close to Ben Khalfallah could be affected by it, other players who are of a professional line understand that’s their line of work,” he said. 
“That’s your job, it’s like anything. 
“Being as professional a club as Melbourne Victory is, I think the message from Kevin would be to understand what the bigger picture here is. 
“Successful clubs, they never make it about one person, whether it be the coach or an individual player. It’s about the team and the team is always the most important. 
“Now I’m pretty sure that Kevin’s message would have been that it’s about the team and it’s about the collective and going forward, a decision’s been made and we just need to be professional. He as a coach and players as well and just get the job done.” 
WHAT IT MEANS GOING FORWARD 
If Ben Khalfallah remains on the sidelines, it opens up an opportunity for young wingers Jai Ingham and Mitch Austin. 
Ingham recently re-signed with Victory for the next two seasons, indicating he’s part of the club’s long-term plans, while Austin enjoyed an excellent start to the season before succumbing to injury and losing his spot to Ben Khalfallah. Jai Ingham is seen action against the Western Sydney Wanderers. Source: AAP 
“It’s questionable and it’s debatable whether Ben Khalfallah is in their first XI or not,” Rudan said. 
“They’ve got two very pacy wingers in Ingham and Austin so it’s not like they haven’t got choices to play in that position.” 
With Marco Rojas locked into a spot on one wing, one spot remains open. 
While Ben Khalfallah’s combination of tricks, pace and elite vision made him a tantalising option, now Victory are more likely to look to use breakneck speed down the left-hand side. 
With fullback Daniel Georgievski frequently keen to bomb up the pitch, the fitness and workrate of Austin and Ingham means they’re better options to cover the opposition’s right-sided players. 
“It gives an Austin or an Ingham an opportunity to promote themselves,” Rudan said. 
“It gives them an opportunity to really cement their spot in the starting XI. 
“So there’s always positives and negatives in these type of situations.” View All Comments The latest sports news, in your inbox daily. Email
